formatted_items.content:
Here’s a concise, plain-text set of general stress-management and wellness tips you can paste into your email to Mark Thompson. All are drawn from Jane’s “Wellness & Stress-Management” materials and are suitable for everyday use:

1. Box Breathing (4-4-4-4)  
   Inhale through the nose for 4 seconds, hold for 4, exhale for 4, hold again for 4. Repeat 4 rounds to quickly calm the nervous system.

2. Two-Minute Body Scan  
   Sit comfortably, close your eyes, and mentally scan from head to toe, noticing and softening any areas of tension as you breathe naturally.

3. Mini Progressive Muscle Relaxation  
   Tense the shoulders, arms, and hands for 5–7 seconds, then release for 10–15 seconds. Repeat twice to ease muscle tightness and signal relaxation.

4. 5-Senses Grounding Pause  
   Name (silently or aloud) one thing you can see, hear, feel, smell, and taste. This quick mindfulness check-in brings attention to the present moment.

5. Desk Stretch Sequence  
   • Slow neck rolls (3 each direction)  
   • Shoulder rolls (5 forward, 5 back)  
   • Chest opener: clasp hands behind back, lift for 15 s  
   • Standing forward fold for 20 s  
   These brief movements boost circulation and reduce stiffness.

6. Five-Minute Movement Break  
   Walk briskly, climb a flight of stairs, or do marching-in-place for five minutes. Even short bursts of activity lower stress hormones and re-energize the body.

Feel free to adjust wording or order as needed for Mark’s email.

final_output:
Here’s a concise, plain-text set of general stress-management and wellness tips you can paste into your email to Mark Thompson. All are drawn from Jane’s “Wellness & Stress-Management” materials and are suitable for everyday use:

1. Box Breathing (4-4-4-4)  
   Inhale through the nose for 4 seconds, hold for 4, exhale for 4, hold again for 4. Repeat 4 rounds to quickly calm the nervous system.

2. Two-Minute Body Scan  
   Sit comfortably, close your eyes, and mentally scan from head to toe, noticing and softening any areas of tension as you breathe naturally.

3. Mini Progressive Muscle Relaxation  
   Tense the shoulders, arms, and hands for 5–7 seconds, then release for 10–15 seconds. Repeat twice to ease muscle tightness and signal relaxation.

4. 5-Senses Grounding Pause  
   Name (silently or aloud) one thing you can see, hear, feel, smell, and taste. This quick mindfulness check-in brings attention to the present moment.

5. Desk Stretch Sequence  
   • Slow neck rolls (3 each direction)  
   • Shoulder rolls (5 forward, 5 back)  
   • Chest opener: clasp hands behind back, lift for 15 s  
   • Standing forward fold for 20 s  
   These brief movements boost circulation and reduce stiffness.

6. Five-Minute Movement Break  
   Walk briskly, climb a flight of stairs, or do marching-in-place for five minutes. Even short bursts of activity lower stress hormones and re-energize the body.

Feel free to adjust wording or order as needed for Mark’s email.
